The experts expressed deep concern about the failure of governments to achieve an immediate ceasefire and prevent genocide. They emphasized that the Palestinian people were at grave risk of genocide. The report was generated by Reuters, and The Print bears no responsibility for its content.A group of experts from the United Nations stated that there is growing evidence of genocidal incitement against the Palestinian people, with grave violations committed by Israel. The experts expressed concern over the failure of governments to achieve an immediate ceasefire and the support of certain governments for Israel's strategy against Gaza's population. Earlier warnings by UN experts had highlighted the Palestinian people's grave risk of genocide. This summary is based on an article from Reuters.

item.title: Russian court jails artist Skochilenko for seven years over anti-war protest
item.description: Russian artist and musician Alexandra Skochilenko has been sentenced to seven years in a prison colony after being found guilty of knowingly spreading fake news about the Russian army's behavior in Ukraine. Skochilenko, 33, replaced price tags in a supermarket in St Petersburg with small pieces of paper calling for an end to Russia's war in Ukraine and criticizing the authorities. She denied the charge of spreading false information about the army.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.

item.title: Mrinal Sen tribute film directed by Anjan Dutt to be screened in 29th KIFF
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The 29th Kolkata International Film Festival, starting on December 5, will screen the movie "Chalchitra Ekhon" directed by Anjan Dutt as a tribute to filmmaker Mrinal Sen on his 100th birth anniversary. The film is based on Dutt's real-life experiences with Sen, who was his mentor and had cast him in the film "Chalchitra" in 1981. The festival will also have a tribute section for Sen, featuring restored versions of his classic films. Mrinal Sen, known for exploring social and political issues in his films, passed away in 2018. Dutt produced "Chalchitra Ekhon" and wanted to depict their unique relationship in the movie.

item.title: J-K Police attaches orchard land under UAPA in Pulwama
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The Special Investigation Unit of Jammu and Kashmir Police has attached nearly one acre of orchard land in Pulwama district under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act. This action was taken after explosives were found on the land earlier this year. A notice has been installed outside the orchard, informing the public about the attachment and prohibiting the owner from selling, transferring, or leasing the property. The authorities also warned the public against purchasing the land. This report is generated by PTI news service.

item.title: Businessman, YouTuber booked on BJP MLA’s complaint in UP’s Bhadohi
item.description: The police in Bhadohi, Uttar Pradesh have registered a case against a local businessman and a YouTuber for alleged criminal conspiracy, based on a complaint by BJP MLA Dinanath Bhaskar. The duo has also been booked under the SC/ST Act, as the MLA accused them of targeting him because he belongs to the Dalit community. Bhaskar claimed that businessman Vineet Jaiswal falsely accused him of accepting Rs 23 lakh for a ticket in the urban local body elections. Additionally, the MLA accused YouTuber Vipul Pandey of publishing biased news reports on the issue. The allegations were first made by Jaiswal in a letter shared with local journalists in May, but the MLA did not explain why he filed a complaint six months later. The police have registered an FIR and are investigating the matter.

item.title: India urges Canada to respect Vienna Convention amid reports of disturbances at Indian events
item.description: India has called on Canada to respect the Vienna Convention on diplomatic relations after reports of disturbances caused by Khalistani elements at an Indian High Commission consular camp in Canada. The Indian Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) spokesperson, Arindam Bagchi, clarified that there were inaccurate social media reports regarding the incidents. Bagchi emphasized that consular camps are regularly organized by the Indian High Commission and consulates in Canada, and despite attempts by radical elements to cause trouble, the recent camp near Vancouver was held successfully. He also mentioned that no complaint had been received regarding alleged attacks on the Indian community during Diwali celebrations in Canada. The MEA spokesperson further addressed the ongoing diplomatic standoff between India and Canada, which began when Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau alleged the involvement of "agents of the Indian government" in the killing of a Khalistani terrorist. India rejected these allegations, expelled a Canadian diplomat, and emphasized that Canada has not presented any evidence to support its claims. The article concludes by mentioning that Canada pulled out 41 diplomats from India and halted visa and consular services in certain consulates, while India suspended visa services to Canada but later resumed them for four categories after a security review.

item.title: Resumption of bilateral military ties, Taiwan — what Biden & Xi discussed at crucial meeting in US
item.description: US President Joe Biden met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Woodside, California, to discuss various issues, including the resumption of military ties and the Taiwan issue. The two countries have agreed to restart high-level military communications, defense policy coordination talks, maritime consultative agreement meetings, and telephone conversations between theatre commanders. Biden emphasized the importance of these communications to avoid miscalculations and conflicts. The leaders also addressed cooperation in combating global illicit drug manufacturing and trafficking. The meeting took place during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Economic Leaders' Week conference chaired by the US. Despite tensions between the US and China, the leaders expressed their belief that both countries can succeed simultaneously and that turning their backs on each other was not an option. The discussions covered topics such as climate change, human rights, and Taiwan. Biden reiterated the US's support for the one-China policy and opposed any unilateral changes to the status quo. He also raised concerns about human rights abuses in Xinjiang, Tibet, and Hong Kong. The article also briefly mentions Biden's remarks on the Israel-Hamas conflict and the need for a two-state solution.

item.title: Aparna Enterprises expands its retail footprint with the launch of UNISPACE in Bengaluru
item.description: Aparna Enterprises Limited has launched its fifth UNISPACE retail store in Bengaluru, India. UNISPACE offers a range of home improvement products and services, including uPVC and Aluminium windows and doors, tiles, and modular kitchen and wardrobe solutions. The store features stunning vitrified tile collections, uPVC and aluminium doors and windows, and kitchen and wardrobe designs. UNISPACE aims to provide personalized service and expert consultation to customers. The company is well-positioned to leverage the growing opportunities in the building material market, which is projected to register a CAGR growth of 8% to 9% over the next five years. Aparna Enterprises Limited is a part of the Aparna Group and is known for its high-quality products and adherence to standards.

item.title: Grand Opening of Amista Clinic at Banjara Hills
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Amista Clinic, a comprehensive cosmetology care facility, has announced the opening of its third branch in Banjara Hills, Hyderabad. The clinic offers advanced services and personalized treatments for skin, hair, body, laser, and other cosmetic treatments. It is equipped with the latest technology and has a team of experienced doctors. To celebrate the grand opening, Amista Clinic will host an event featuring a clinic tour, Q&A sessions, and special discounts for attendees.

item.title: Puravankara Secures Redevelopment Rights for 2 Housing Societies in Mumbai, with a GDV Potential of Rs 1,500 Crore
item.description: Real estate developer Puravankara Limited has acquired the residential redevelopment rights for two housing societies in the western suburbs of Mumbai, marking its entry into the redevelopment space in the western region. The project, located in the heart of Lokhandwala in Andheri West, spans 3 acres and has an estimated development potential of 5.8 lakh square feet carpet area. Approximately 3.65 lakh square feet will be available for sale, with a potential gross development value of INR 1,500 crore. Puravankara plans to launch two new projects in Pune this fiscal year as part of its expansion plan.

item.title: Silicon Valley’s elite engage with Piyush Goyal: India’s investment appeal in the spotlight
item.description: Indian Minister of Commerce and Industry, Piyush Goyal, recently engaged with Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and venture capitalists to highlight India's business ecosystem and potential for investments. Goyal emphasized India's young talent, vibrant economy, and resilience within the Indian business landscape. The minister's outreach to Silicon Valley aims to strengthen India's position in the international investment arena and foster economic ties between India and the United States. Goyal also met with chartered accountants from the San Francisco chapter of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) to tap into their expertise and network, urging them to contribute to bilateral trade and commerce. Additionally, he discussed collaboration opportunities with YouTube CEO Neal Mohan and discussed how India's semiconductor ecosystem presents vast opportunities for collaboration with Micron Technology CEO Sanjay Mehrotra. Goyal's efforts in Silicon Valley showcase the Indian government's commitment to attracting foreign investments and fostering a collaborative ecosystem for global business leaders.

item.title: Poland’s Allegro sees higher holiday-quarter earnings after Q3 core profit beat
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Poland's largest e-commerce platform, Allegro, expects a 20%-23% increase in earnings in the holiday quarter. In the third quarter, the company's core profit exceeded expectations, with adjusted EBITDA rising 32.4% to 778 million zlotys. The company reported a 10.5% increase in gross merchandise value (GMV) in Poland, and it anticipates GMV to grow 9%-11% in the fourth quarter. Allegro plans to expand its marketplace to Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, and Croatia next year. The number of active buyers in Poland reached 14.5 million, and Allegro's black week campaign has had a "solid start."

item.title: India logs 18 new Covid cases
item.description: India has reported 18 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total number of active cases to 158, according to data from the Union Health Ministry. The death toll stands at 533,295. The country's total COVID-19 case tally is 450,015,510, with a recovery rate of 98.81%. The case fatality rate is 1.19%. The health ministry's website also states that 220.67 crore doses of the COVID-19 vaccine have been administered in India. This report is auto-generated from the PTI news service. ThePrint is not responsible for its content.

item.title: Xi tells US firms China ready to be partner and friend
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Chinese President Xi Jinping assured American executives in San Francisco that China is ready to be a partner and friend of the United States, emphasizing the potential for bilateral cooperation. This statement came as China seeks to reassure global business and counter its struggles in attracting foreign investment. The remarks were made during a dinner with U.S. executives on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, following talks between Xi and U.S. President Joe Biden aimed at stabilizing relations between the two largest economies. Xi received applause and a standing ovation upon entering the room and reiterated China's commitment to not pursue hegemony or expansion and to avoid engaging in a cold war or hot war. Additionally, he expressed sympathy for the American people regarding the fentanyl crisis and mentioned prior discussions with Biden on curbing fentanyl production. The event was attended by nearly 400 individuals, including business and government officials, academics, and prominent executives from major U.S. companies.

item.title: Cong leaders united, party will win Rajasthan polls: Rahul Gandhi
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. He made these remarks while addressing reporters at the airport in Jaipur before heading to Tara Nagar in Churu for a campaign rally. Gandhi was accompanied by Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot, Rajasthan Pradesh Congress Committee Chief Govind Singh Dotasra, and former Deputy Chief Minister Sachin Pilot. Gandhi also has plans to address public rallies in Nohar (Hanumangarh) and Sadulshahar (Sriganganagar). item.title: Israeli President Isaac Herzog says Israel cannot leave a vacuum in Gaza- FT
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Israeli President Isaac Herzog stated that Israel cannot leave a vacuum in Gaza and must maintain a strong force there to prevent the resurgence of Hamas, according to the Financial Times. He emphasized the need to consider mechanisms for governance in Gaza to avoid turning it into a base for terrorism. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu previously mentioned that Israel would have security responsibility for Gaza indefinitely after the war, but the United States disagreed, asserting that Palestinians should govern the enclave once the conflict with Hamas ends. President Joe Biden reiterated support for a two-state solution and warned against occupying Gaza. The article also mentions details about the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas, including casualties and damage caused.

item.title: Fire in Chinese coal firm’s office kills 25
item.description: A fire at a coal company's office building in China's Shanxi province has killed 25 people and injured at least 51. The cause of the fire is still unknown and is currently under investigation. This incident adds to a series of deadly fires and accidents that have occurred in China, including a hospital fire in Beijing that resulted in 29 deaths. China's coal industry has also been facing scrutiny for safety issues in recent months.A fire at a coal company's office building in China's Shanxi province has resulted in the deaths of 25 people. The fire occurred at the Yongju Coal Industry joint building in the town of Shanxi, a major coal-producing region. Initially, 11 deaths and 51 injuries were reported, but the death toll increased twice. The cause of the fire is still unknown, and there has been no response from the Yongju Coal Industry. This incident adds to public anger over previous deadly fires in China, including one that occurred in a hospital in Beijing in April. China's coal producers have also faced scrutiny due to a series of accidents in mines, leading to production delays for safety inspections. The report is based on information from Reuters, and ThePrint is not responsible for its content.

item.title: Panel set up to probe bus accident in J-K’s Doda
item.description: A three-member panel has been set up by the Jammu and Kashmir administration to investigate the bus accident in Doda district, which claimed the lives of 39 people. The bus skidded off the road and fell into a gorge. One more passenger died from injuries, bringing the total death toll to 39. A committee has been formed to inquire into the circumstances of the accident and is expected to submit a detailed report within a week. Local residents attribute frequent accidents in the area to poor road conditions, reckless driving, and vehicle overloading.

item.title: Philippines rejects China’s call for prior notice on resupply missions
item.description: The Philippines stated that it is not obligated to inform China about its resupply missions in the South China Sea. The Department of Foreign Affairs called on China to remove its illegal structures within the Philippines' exclusive economic zone and be accountable for the damage caused. China has accused the Philippines of illegally entering its waters during resupply missions, while the Philippines asserts that these missions are legitimate. The Permanent Court of Arbitration ruled in 2016 that China's claim over the South China Sea had no legal basis, a ruling supported by the US Defense Secretary during a meeting with his Manila counterpart. Since 1999, when the Philippines grounded the Sierra Madre ship at the disputed Second Thomas Shoal, China has requested its removal based on an alleged agreement that the Philippines denies. The shoal lies well within the Philippines' exclusive economic zone.

item.title: Man who cheated people by forging cheques held after 3 yrs in Thane
item.description: A man from Thane, Maharashtra, who had been on the run for over three years, has been arrested by the police for allegedly cheating multiple individuals through forging cheques and other documents. The arrest followed a complaint from a bank manager stating that the accused had fraudulently withdrawn Rs 11,92,500 from an account using forged cheques and diverted the funds to different bank accounts. The police investigated the case and identified the culprit, who frequently changed his location. Acting on a tip-off, the police apprehended him near a college in Mira Road. During interrogation, it was discovered that he was involved in four other cases of cheating based on forged documents in various police stations in Thane, Palghar, and Nagpur. The accused had a history of similar crimes dating back to 2004 and had previously been arrested in some of those cases as well.

item.title: Rupee edges lower tracking Asian peers, state-run banks on offer
item.description: The Indian rupee weakened against the US dollar, following a trend among other Asian currencies. However, the rupee's losses were limited by US dollar sales from state-run banks, likely on behalf of clients. The rupee's volatility has increased but remains within a range of 83 to 83.30. The domestic currency had previously reached its lifetime low of 83.42. Investors are now awaiting US initial jobless claims data for the preceding week.The Indian rupee weakened against the U.S. dollar, following the trend of other Asian currencies, but the downside was limited by dollar sales from state-run banks on behalf of clients. The rupee's value was at 83.2125 against the dollar, slightly higher than its previous close at 83.1425. The rupee had experienced its best day in almost two months on Wednesday. The dollar index was higher at 104.48, supported by better-than-expected retail sales numbers in the U.S. Additionally, the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield rebounded after falling on expectations of possible policy rate reductions by the Federal Reserve next year. The rupee's volatility has increased recently but is expected to remain within a range of 83 to 83.30. Dollar sales from state-run banks helped limit the rupee's losses. Investors are now awaiting U.S. initial jobless claims data for the previous week.

item.title: Ex-army man gunned down, 2 armed assailants lynched by mob in Bihar’s Rohtas
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Two individuals were killed by a mob in Bihar's Rohtas district after they shot and killed an ex-army man. A third alleged assailant was also attacked and is receiving treatment at a government hospital. The deceased ex-army man has been identified as Bijendra Singh, while the two lynched individuals were Mithilesh Kumar and Aditya Kumar. The reason behind the ex-army man's killing is unknown, and a special team has been set up to investigate the murder and subsequent lynching.

item.title: India’s record merchandise trade deficit in Oct likely to be a one-off – analysts
item.description: India's merchandise trade deficit widened sharply in October to a record level of $31.46 billion. This increase was driven by a rise in imports, particularly in oil, gold, and silver imports ahead of the Diwali festive season. However, analysts believe that this spike in imports is likely to be a temporary outlier, and they expect the trade deficit to moderate considerably in November and December. The easing of oil prices also provides some relief. Despite the high trade deficit in October, economists retain their current account deficit (CAD) estimates, expecting it to normalize from November onwards.

item.title: Rohit Sharma is India’s real hero: Nasser Hussain
item.description: Former England captain Nasser Hussain has praised Indian captain Rohit Sharma for changing the culture of the Indian cricket team with his fearless playing style in the ongoing World Cup. India had been criticized for playing timid cricket in the last two T20 World Cups, but they have been relentless in this tournament, reaching their first final in 12 years. Hussain believes that Sharma is the real hero of the Indian team, who has brought about a change in their approach. India's aggressive batting, led by Sharma, has been a key factor in their success. India will face the winner of the second semifinal between South Africa and Australia in the final.

item.title: Rescue hopes for men trapped in India tunnel rest on new drill equipment
item.description: Two of the 40 men trapped inside a collapsed highway tunnel in the Indian Himalayas were treated for nausea and headaches, as they entered their fifth day confined in the rubble. Rescue efforts have been focused on drilling through the fallen rock to create space for a pipe that can be used to pull the men to safety. However, progress has been hindered by falling debris. Authorities are confident that an advanced drilling machine brought in from New Delhi will expedite the rescue operation. The tunnel is part of a major highway project, and the trapped men have been provided with food, water, and oxygen through a pipe, and are in contact with rescuers via walkie-talkies.

item.title: ‘Incredible’ Shami one of the top operators, India is the best team in the world: Williamson
item.description: India defeated New Zealand by 70 runs in the World Cup semifinal, securing their spot in the final. New Zealand captain Kane Williamson praised Indian pacer Mohammed Shami, hailing him as one of the best bowlers in the world. Shami's impressive seven-wicket haul helped restrict New Zealand to 327 while chasing a target of 398. With this performance, Shami became the leading wicket-taker in the tournament despite missing four matches earlier. Williamson acknowledged that India is the best team in the world and commended their consistent performance. He also praised Virat Kohli's 50th ODI century, describing him as the best cricketer who keeps getting better. The controversy surrounding the pitch was brushed aside by Williamson, who stated that it was a good surface to play on. Looking ahead, he expressed optimism about the future of the New Zealand team, mentioning the emergence of new players. Daryl Mitchell's exceptional innings of 134 was also applauded by Williamson, acknowledging his contribution in the match.

item.title: Jaishankar presides over repatriation of 2 stolen idols in UK
item.description: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar presided over a repatriation ceremony in London for two 8th-century temple idols stolen from India and discovered in England. The idols, stolen from a temple in Uttar Pradesh in the late 1970s and early 1980s, were recovered by the High Commission of India in London with support from India Pride Project and Art Recovery International. Jaishankar unveiled the idols at India House and emphasized the importance of legal and transparent cultural exchanges. The idols, known as Yogini Chamunda and Yogini Gomukhi, are part of a group of 64 divine Yoginis worshipped as goddesses. The Lokhari temple is believed to have had 20 Yogini statues, some of which were stolen, broken, or hidden by local villagers. This is the fifth time that important pieces of cultural heritage have been returned to India through negotiations with possessors.

item.title: Israel: 2 Knesset members sanctioned for false claims about Oct 7, war
item.description: Two Arab lawmakers, Ra’am Party MK Iman Khatib-Yasin and Hadash-Ta’al Party MK Aida Touma-Sliman, have been suspended from the Knesset for making false claims about the October 7 massacre and the war against Hamas. Khatib-Yasin received a one-month suspension and a two-week pay freeze for denying the Hamas atrocities, while Touma-Sliman was suspended for two months and received a two-week pay freeze for falsely accusing the IDF of attacking operating rooms at Shifa Hospital in Gaza City. Israeli Justice Minister Yariv Levin has vowed to criminalize the denial of Hamas's October 7 atrocities.

item.title: IDF finds evidence Hamas hid weapons in Gaza hospital
item.description: The Israel Defence Forces (IDF) have discovered evidence of Hamas using hospitals in Gaza for terrorist purposes. The IDF found an operational headquarters, weapons, and technological equipment in the MRI building at Shifa Hospital. Special units under the command of the IDF's 36th Armoured Division are operating in a targeted manner to locate infrastructure and hidden means of warfare. During their search, IDF forces encountered and eliminated terrorists. They also found unique technological means, combat equipment, and an operational headquarters belonging to Hamas in different departments of the hospital. The IDF is extracting intelligence information and ensuring the safety of medical staff while continuing operations in the hospital area.

item.title: Families of hostages, murdered of Oct 7 go on Latin American diplomatic push
item.description: Israeli diplomatic missions, consisting of family members of Israeli hostages held in Gaza and victims of Hamas attacks, have expanded to Latin America. The first mission arrived in Mexico and is expected to meet with Mexican government officials, members of the Jewish community, and the Catholic vice-cardinal. The delegation aims to raise awareness of the issue of returning the abductees and combat anti-Semitism. This is the sixth group to leave Israel in the past two weeks, with previous delegations visiting London, Rome, the United States, Canada, and Belgium. The family members hope to exert international pressure for the return of the abductees and actions against Hamas.

item.title: Turkish President labels Israel a “terrorist state,” Netanyahu hits back
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has branded Israel as a "terrorist state" and vowed to ensure that Israel's political and military leaders face trial in international courts for their actions in Gaza. In response, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused Erdogan of supporting the "terror state of Hamas." Erdogan also accused Netanyahu of threatening Gaza with nuclear bombs. Erdogan had previously cancelled a planned visit to Israel, stating that Turkey would not approve of Tel Aviv committing atrocities. The Israeli Foreign Ministry responded to a UN Security Council resolution calling for "extended humanitarian pauses" in Gaza by demanding the release of hostages held by Hamas. There are reports of a potential deal to free captives in exchange for a pause in fighting.

item.title: Drugs worth PKR 5 bn seized from Pakistani goods in Malaysia, 5 held
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Malaysian authorities have seized drugs worth PKR 5 billion in Malaysia from Pakistani goods and arrested five local suspects. The drugs, which included over 100 kg of cocaine and 411 kg of methenamine, were found in a Pakistani container carrying onions. The Malaysian Customs and Narcotics Crime Investigation Department conducted a raid and informed Pakistani authorities. In a separate raid in Gwadar, the Anti-Narcotics Force seized a large consignment of drugs, including hashish, ice, and morphine. The drugs were made in Afghanistan and were found hidden in various locations. The seized drugs were set on fire after being confiscated.

item.title: Pakistan: Air pollution crisis intensifies in Lahore
item.description:
Lahore, Pakistan is facing a severe air pollution crisis as the air quality index (AQI) has reached alarming levels. After a brief period of relatively normal air quality, the city saw a sudden spike with a maximum AQI of 401, marking it as extremely unsafe for breathing. Although there was a slight improvement in the afternoon with the AQI dropping to 188, the air quality deteriorated again in the evening, reaching an AQI of 236. As a result, Lahore now ranks third on the list of the most polluted cities globally. The current readings indicate a severe threat to public health.
Different areas of Lahore showed varying levels of air pollution, with Fida Hussain House reporting an AQI of 364 and WWF Pakistan at 231. The decline in air quality during winter months, from October to February, is a common occurrence in Lahore. Crop burning by farmers in the Punjab province contributes to smog, while weather changes trap pollutants in the air for longer periods.
The main contributors to air pollution in Lahore are vehicle and industrial emissions, smoke from brick kilns, burning of crop residue and waste, dust from construction sites, and deforestation. Temperature inversion worsens winter air pollution by preventing the upward movement of pollutants and causing their accumulation.
Experts recommend providing real-time air quality data to the public with greater detail to help individuals protect themselves and contribute to efforts against air pollution. Reducing industrial and vehicular emissions is crucial for improving air quality. Urgent and coordinated efforts are needed to address the root causes of air pollution and protect the health and well-being of Lahore's residents.

item.title: UN Security Council adopts resolution urging humanitarian pauses in Gaza

item.title: Work on monument to commemorate 1st Indians in South Africa to begin soon: Govt
item.description: The South African government has announced that work on a monument to honor the first Indian indentured laborers' arrival in the country will begin soon. The monument, which was supposed to be built in 2010, commemorates the arrival of the first Indians in Durban in 1860 to work on sugar cane plantations. The delay in constructing the monument was due to funding issues and disagreements within the community regarding its design. The provincial KwaZulu-Natal Department of Sport, Arts, and Culture has awarded the tender for the four-million-rand monument, and it will be constructed at Ushaka Beach in Durban. The monument will include an arch with a bell tower, symbolizing the bell used to call workers to work during times of slavery and indenture. The design will also incorporate the names of the two ships that brought the indentured laborers engraved on metal sheets. While some members of the community have expressed satisfaction with the announcement, others believe that their original proposal, depicting a sugar cane cutter and his wife in a field, was ignored. Despite the differing opinions, there is a call for the monument to be completed as soon as possible, emphasizing the importance of unity in diversity.

item.title: EAM Jaishankar asks Canada to share evidence on India’s alleged link in Nijjar killing
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has accused India of involvement in the killing of Khalistani terrorist Hardeep Singh Nijjar. In response, Indian External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar has requested credible evidence to support these claims. Jaishankar stated that no evidence has been provided thus far and urged the Canadian government to share any evidence they may have. He highlighted the accommodation of violent and extreme political opinions advocating separatism from India within Canadian politics. Jaishankar also emphasized the need for responsibility in exercising freedom of speech and expression in Canada. The article mentions incidents of attacks on Indian diplomats in Canada and a recent incident where Indian High Commissioner Vikram Doraiswami was stopped from entering a gurdwara in Glasgow. The ongoing diplomatic row between India and Canada has led to the withdrawal of diplomats and visa services. India has rejected the allegations made by Canada and stated that no evidence has been presented.

Bhaya is a co-owner of a Delaware law firm and specializes in representing individuals who have been seriously injured due to unsafe decisions made by businesses and individuals. She has been involved in Delaware politics and is a member of the Delaware Democratic Party's State Executive Committee. Bhaya has also been actively involved in advocating for the rights of the LGBTQ+ community and helping pro-choice Democratic women get elected to office. She is the first South Asian Indian to be admitted to the Delaware Bar Association and continues to work towards promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion in the legal profession and in politics. Bhaya is a graduate of Northeastern University School of Law.

He believes that the US, with its advanced technology and rescue expertise, could have a significant impact on the rescue efforts and potentially save lives. Thanedar has requested USAID to engage directly with India to discuss potential avenues for US assistance. He also wants to be kept informed of any developments and actions taken by USAID in response to this situation.

item.title: Presidents Biden, Xi meet near San Francisco to establish working relationship
item.description: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping met at a mansion in northern California to improve their strained relationship. Both leaders stressed the importance of avoiding confrontation and focusing on cooperation. They discussed global challenges such as climate change and artificial intelligence. Xi emphasized that conflicts and confrontations have negative consequences for both countries and stated that competition is not the prevailing trend. The discussion took place in a cordial but not overly friendly atmosphere. Xi pointed out the various challenges the world is facing, including the impact of the COVID pandemic and rising protectionism. The leaders agreed that the China-US relationship should benefit both nations and contribute to human progress. Biden expressed appreciation for their candid conversations and emphasized the need for clear understanding between the two leaders.

Jaishankar also discussed India's position in the global markets and its significance in preventing smaller countries from being ignored by suppliers. Regarding the Russia-Ukraine war, Jaishankar emphasized the balance between principles and interests, expressing India's powerful interest in maintaining its relationship with Russia. He further discussed India's role in global institutions like the G20 and BRICS, describing India as partly evolutionary and partly revolutionary in its approach to reforms. Overall, Jaishankar highlighted India's unique position in the evolving global landscape and its recent achievements ranging from handling COVID-19 to economic changes and digital technology adoption.

item.title: Xi says ‘not an option’ for US, China to turn their backs on each other
item.description: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping met for their first face-to-face encounter in over a year. The summit, held on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), aimed to address escalating tensions between the two nations. The meeting covered various issues such as fentanyl supplies, military communication, climate change, countering narcotics trafficking, and artificial intelligence. While the relationship between the US and China has had its challenges, the leaders emphasized the importance of maintaining open lines of communication and working together on global challenges.

item.title: Jaishankar concludes ‘timely’ visit to UK amid ‘substantial progress’ on FTA

Roadblocks have been set up at strategic locations to apprehend underage drivers, and their vehicles and motorcycles will be impounded at police stations. The CTO also warned parents about potential legal consequences and urged them not to allow their underage children to drive. The traffic police have issued 22,000 challans against young drivers throughout the year, highlighting the seriousness of the issue. The crackdown was prompted by a car accident involving a teenage boy who collided with the victims' car, driving recklessly.

item.title: Emraan Hashmi gets candid about playing an antagonist in ‘Tiger 3’
item.description: Emraan Hashmi, known for his romantic roles, has revealed that he will be playing an antagonist in the upcoming movie 'Tiger 3'. Initially skeptical, Emraan agreed to the role after discovering the depth and multiple shades to his character. He expressed that playing this role was an opportunity for him to showcase a different side of his acting skills. Emraan also shared that he has been selective in choosing projects to break away from similar kinds of roles that he has been offered in the past. Directed by Maneesh Sharma, 'Tiger 3' is the third installment of the Tiger franchise and stars Salman Khan, Katrina Kaif, and Emraan Hashmi. It is part of the YRF spy universe and will feature cameo appearances from Shah Rukh Khan and a post-credit scene with Hrithik Roshan. The film revolves around a new mission involving Ra&W agent Tiger and ISI agent Zoya, just like the previous installments.

item.title: Researchers reveal how ribosomes help to recognise RNA crosslinking damage
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Scientists at the Gene Centre Munich have discovered a new mechanism by which cells detect and repair crosslinking damage to single-stranded RNA. Previous research had focused on repairing crosslinking damage to DNA, but this study reveals the harmful effects of such damage on protein synthesis. The researchers used a novel approach to induce and study RNA damage in the absence of DNA damage, leading to the identification of the ribosome as a sensor for crosslinking damage. The findings have implications for the mechanisms of action of commonly used anti-cancer drugs. Aldehydes, which are produced in the body through metabolic processes, are toxic because they bind to macromolecules like DNA, RNA, and proteins and crosslink them.

item.title: WhatsApp channels cross 500 million monthly active users
item.description: WhatsApp channels, a platform for sharing information with followers, has reached 500 million monthly active users, according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg. Channels allow individuals, organizations, and teams to share content with followers, and are separate from private chats. WhatsApp plans to add more features and expand channels based on user feedback. Indian celebrities, including actor-singer Diljit Dosanjh and chef Ranveer Brar, have praised the platform for its ability to connect with fans and share personal content. WhatsApp also recently introduced stickers on channels as a new feature.

item.title: Goa CM flags off rally to spread awareness among people about central govt schemes
item.description: Goa Chief Minister Pramod Sawant has launched a rally called "Vikasit Bharat" to spread awareness about the welfare schemes of the central government in order to increase the number of eligible beneficiaries. The rally will visit every panchayat in the state to inform people about these schemes and provide them with application forms to access the benefits. Sawant also mentioned that Goa has become an open defecation-free state and has provided tap water to every household. He plans to commend panchayats that have performed well in these areas.

The blast occurred in the afternoon while the train was at the outer signal. Smoke was found billowing from a bag on an upper berth, and two passengers admitted to having placed gunpowder in the bag for manufacturing firecrackers. item.title: I was trying to take the pace off the ball, says seven-star Shami
item.description: Indian pacer Mohammed Shami took seven wickets, leading to New Zealand's downfall in their chase. He employed the strategy of reducing the pace of the ball to force the batsmen into making mistakes. Shami's figures of 7 for 57 were the best by an Indian bowler in the tournament, and he also completed 50 wickets in just 17 games. Shami expressed concerns about the dew factor but was relieved that it didn't affect the match. He mentioned his eagerness to make a comeback into the playing 11 and felt terrible for dropping New Zealand captain Kane Williamson. Shami expressed his joy in reaching the World Cup final and emphasized the team's determination to seize this opportunity.

item.title: Part of Chandrayaan-3 launch vehicle makes uncontrolled re-entry into Earth’s atmosphere: ISRO
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has announced that the cryogenic upper stage of the LVM3 M4 launch vehicle, which successfully launched the Chandrayaan-3 spacecraft into orbit on July 14, re-entered the Earth's atmosphere on November 15. The ISRO stated that the rocket body re-entered the atmosphere over the north Pacific Ocean and did not pass over India. The re-entry occurred 124 days after the launch, within the recommended 25-year rule for low-Earth orbit objects. The upper stage had undergone passivation to remove residual propellant and energy sources, in line with international space debris guidelines. The ISRO emphasized India's commitment to preserving the long-term sustainability of outer space activities.

item.title: “Hamas violating rules of war by having its headquarters in hospital”: White House
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Kirby stated that the hospital is an active legitimate hospital, and they want to protect its patients. The US did not provide prior approval to the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) for their raid on the hospital because they do not expect Israel to give advance notice of its military operations. Kirby further mentioned that Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad use hospitals in the Gaza Strip, including Al Shifa, to conceal and support their military operations. The IDF has confirmed that they are conducting operations in the hospital based on intelligence information and operational necessity, with the goal of defeating Hamas and rescuing hostages. The IDF has repeatedly warned Hamas about the misuse of the hospital, and despite evacuation efforts, military activities within the hospital did not cease. The IDF emphasized that their war is against Hamas, not the people of Gaza, and it is doing everything possible to minimize harm to civilians and facilitate the transfer of medical supplies and food. Israeli troops have also captured several Hamas governmental buildings in Gaza City.

item.title: “Sickening to see you laugh”: Masaba Gupta on Ramiz Raja’s reaction to racist comment about mother Neena, Vivian Richards
item.description: Masaba Gupta, a celebrity designer and actor, has criticized former Pakistan Cricket Board chairman Ramiz Raja for laughing at a racial remark about her parents, Neena Gupta and Vivian Alexander Richards. In a tweet, she expressed her disappointment at Raja's behavior and called for him to step into the future. The incident occurred on a chat show in Pakistan, where Raja was seen giggling at a crude comment made by a woman about Neena Gupta and Richards. The video went viral, sparking outrage online. Neena Gupta and Vivian Alexander Richards had Masaba out of wedlock and have lived separately throughout their lives.

item.title: One arrested for attack on Delhi woman, daughter
item.description: A 27-year-old man, Ravi Rana, has been arrested in Delhi's Alipur area for his involvement in an attack on a 45-year-old woman and her 21-year-old daughter on Diwali. The victims were shot at by two men while they were on their way to perform a religious ritual. Rakesh Devi, the woman, was a witness in her husband's murder case. Rana, who is Devi's nephew, allegedly hired the men to kill her. The motive behind the attack was the property dispute between the two families, which had escalated previously with Rana's alleged involvement in the murder of Devi's husband. Efforts are being made to apprehend the attackers.

item.title: Vijayvargiya sees Congress’s hand in video purportedly showing Union minister Tomar’s son
item.description: BJP General Secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya claimed that a video allegedly showing Union Minister Narendra Tomar's son discussing financial dealings is a ploy by the Congress party. Tomar is seen as a potential Chief Minister candidate if the BJP wins the upcoming assembly polls in Madhya Pradesh. The Congress party has requested that government agencies investigate the video. The BJP and Tomar have denied the authenticity of the video, stating that it is fake. Vijayvargiya accused the Congress of wanting to defame the BJP during the elections, claiming that the video was released from Canada. Tomar, who went from being a corporator to a union minister, is said to have had a transparent life, according to Vijayvargiya.

item.title: Being the semifinal, there was pressure on us: Rohit Sharma
item.description: India defeated New Zealand by 70 runs in the World Cup semifinal, securing a place in the final. Indian captain Rohit Sharma admitted feeling some pressure in the semifinal but praised his team's performance and calmness. He attributed India's successful run chase to their imposing total of 397 for 4. New Zealand captain Kane Williamson commended India's outstanding cricket and admitted that chasing 400 runs was always going to be challenging. He praised his team's effort and mentioned the stellar performances of Rachin Ravindra and Daryl Mitchell.

item.title: From Gavaskar to Djokovic, sports world hails ‘Super Human’ Virat Kohli
item.description: Virat Kohli, the Indian cricket team captain, has achieved a remarkable milestone by scoring his 50th century in One Day Internationals (ODIs). This feat was praised by various renowned figures from the sports world. Tennis legend Novak Djokovic congratulated Kohli on his achievement. Sunil Gavaskar, former Indian cricketer, described Kohli's performance as "superhuman" and acknowledged that he has raised the bar even higher after Sachin Tendulkar set it. Kohli is also the first player to score 700 runs in a single World Cup edition. Yuvraj Singh, the 2011 World Cup-winning hero, hailed Kohli as the greatest of this generation. Former batter VVS Laxman praised Kohli's sense of occasion and incredible knock, stating that he is now in a league of his own. Many other players and cricket personalities expressed their admiration for Kohli's achievement, including Akash Chopra, Irfan Pathan, Robin Uthappa, Shikhar Dhawan, Suresh Raina, Wasim Akram, Shoaib Malik, Kevin Pietersen, Michael Vaughan, Brad Hogg, Ian Bishop, and Rashid Khan. Kohli celebrated his milestone by bowing down to Tendulkar in the stands, receiving applause from the cricket legend.

item.title: Shut up, stop taking potshots at India: Gavaskar on pitch controversy
item.description: Legendary cricketer Sunil Gavaskar has dismissed conspiracy theories surrounding the pitch for the World Cup semifinal between India and New Zealand, calling those spreading such rumors "morons." Reports had emerged before the match that the Indian cricket team management had requested a "slow pitch" to assist the home team's spinners. However, India went on to win the semifinal by 70 runs, with pacer Mohammed Shami taking seven wickets. Gavaskar emphasized that the pitch alteration was for the benefit of both teams and criticized people for talking about potential pitch changes in future matches. The International Cricket Council (ICC) clarified that the independent pitch consultant was consulted before the change of surface. Former England skipper Michael Vaughan expressed his opinion that a fresh pitch should have been used for the semifinal.

item.title: Stranded 4-ton whale calf pushed back into sea after 40 hours in Ratnagiri district
item.description: A whale calf stranded on the coast of Ganpatipule in Maharashtra, India, was successfully pushed back into the sea after 40 hours of rescue efforts. The calf, weighing nearly 4 tons, got stuck in the sand near the beach during low tide. Authorities were alerted by locals and tourists, and a rescue operation involving the police, coast guard, and marine experts was initiated. Initial attempts to push the whale calf back into the sea failed, but rescuers kept it hydrated and covered it with cotton. Veterinary doctors provided fluids to keep it alive. After various attempts, including tying the calf with a belt and dragging it, a tugboat was used to drag the whale calf 7 to 8 nautical miles into the sea. Once back in its natural habitat, the calf swam on its own and disappeared in the sea. The operation involved various stakeholders and was considered rare. Precautionary measures have been put in place in case the calf returns to the coast, including the deployment of forest department, police, and district administration personnel.

item.title: Dubai International Chamber launches new international representative office in Frankfurt
item.description: The Dubai International Chamber, operating under Dubai Chambers, has opened a new international representative office in Frankfurt, Germany. This office aims to strengthen the economic relationship between Dubai and Germany, facilitating business, trade, and investments between the two markets. It is part of the "Dubai Global" initiative to attract foreign investment and enable Dubai-based companies to expand globally. The Frankfurt office will provide support to the German business community, showcase Dubai's advantages, and assist Dubai-based companies in expanding into Germany. The goal is to build a network of 50 integrated commercial representative offices for Dubai across five continents by 2030. The Dubai Chamber aims to boost non-oil foreign trade and double the size of the emirate's economy by 2033.

The IMF had previously approved a $3 billion loan in July, with the first tranche of $1.2 billion already released. The agreement is subject to approval from the IMF's executive board, and upon approval, the total disbursements under the program would amount to almost $1.9 billion. The IMF advised Pakistan to continue fiscal consolidation, reduce public debt, and implement reforms in the energy sector. The conclusion of these talks is expected to help stabilize Pakistan's economy ahead of the upcoming general elections.

item.title: India’s trade deficit hits record high in October, largest share of imports from China
item.description: India's trade deficit reached a record high of $31.46 billion in October due to increased imports, particularly gold during the festive season. China remains India's largest import source, followed by Russia, which has climbed in rank due to petroleum and oil product imports. Chinese imports are double that of Russia's. In October, Indian imports amounted to $65.03 billion and exports were $33.57 billion. Gold imports witnessed significant growth with a 95.4% increase month-on-month, reaching $7.23 billion. From April to October, gold imports rose from $23.97 billion to $29.48 billion. On the export side, gems and jewellery exports decreased from $23.95 billion to $18.61 billion due to low demand, including conflicts in Ukraine and Gaza impacting US market interest rates and inflation. The industry suggests focusing more on jewellery exports and expects potential benefits from an amended Special Economic Zones (SEZ) Act. Other declining exports include petroleum products and organic and inorganic chemicals, affected by global oil price changes.

item.title: RBI stops Bajaj Finance from issuing loans under eCOM, Insta EMI Card with immediate effect
item.description: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has banned Bajaj Finance from issuing loans under two products, ecom and insta emi card lending, due to deficiencies in adhering to digital lending guidelines. The RBI stated that Bajaj Finance failed to provide key information to borrowers, and there were deficiencies in the information for other digital loans. The ban will be lifted once the company rectifies these issues.India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has prohibited Bajaj Finance from issuing loans under two digital lending products due to non-compliance with guidelines. The company failed to provide key information to borrowers for its eCOM and Insta EMI Card lending products, as well as other digital loans. The RBI stated that the restrictions will be lifted once the deficiencies are rectified.

item.title: Euro zone banks lose millions of euros to poor IT outsourcing
item.description: Euro zone banks are facing significant financial losses as a result of tech contractors failing to meet their obligations, according to the European Central Bank (ECB). In a recent survey conducted by the ECB, it was found that banks lost €148 million ($160.59 million) in 2022 due to the "unavailability or poor quality of outsourced services," marking a 360% increase from the previous year. The ECB also identified shortcomings in banks' approaches to cyber risks, including hacks, outdated systems, and inadequate outsourcing arrangements. The report highlights the need for banks to properly manage risks arising from reliance on service providers and ensure their IT and cybersecurity risk management aligns with supervisory expectations. The ECB emphasized the importance of addressing these issues to prevent further financial losses and protect against cyber threats.

However, Xpeng expects deliveries in the fourth quarter to double and revenue to exceed estimates. Chinese EV makers, including Xpeng, are facing challenges in competing with Tesla on their home turf due to high production costs. They have also been exporting vehicles to Europe, but face the threat of higher tariffs. Xpeng's net loss per American Depositary Share (ADS) also widened in the third quarter.

item.title: EU asks Amazon to clarify its measures to protect customers
item.description: The European Commission has given Amazon until December 6 to provide more information on the measures it takes to protect customers from illegal products. This request is in line with new online content rules, called the Digital Services Act, which require major online platforms to remove illegal or harmful content or face fines of up to 6% of their global turnover.The European Commission has given Amazon until December 6 to provide more details on how it protects customers from illegal products. This request comes under the new online content rules of the Digital Services Act (DSA), which require major online platforms to take down illegal and harmful content or face fines of up to 6% of their global turnover.

item.title: Can a Balanced Advantage Fund Help you Withstand Market Volatility?
item.description:
Balanced Advantage Funds (BAFs) are hybrid mutual fund schemes that dynamically manage their portfolio between equity and debt based on market conditions. These funds aim to optimize returns by shifting between asset classes. BAFs have the flexibility to invest in equity, debt, or have a balanced exposure to both. This allows them to generate returns in different market conditions, making them suitable for investment through all economic cycles.
BAFs can help in volatile markets by adapting to changing conditions. Unlike traditional approaches with fixed allocation percentages, BAFs can capitalize on opportunities and manage risks effectively. They deliver returns in both bull and bear phases, capturing the upside during market booms and cushioning losses during downturns. BAFs also provide downside mitigation by increasing debt exposure during volatile phases, balancing the risk of equities. Additionally, professional fund managers continuously monitor market trends and adjust allocations for optimal risk-adjusted returns.
BAFs overcome the limitations of other hybrid schemes by offering more flexible equity-debt rebalancing parameters. Traditional hybrid funds may fail to adapt to extreme market movements due to allocation constraints. Aggressive hybrid funds with high equity allocation limits may decline sharply during steep corrections, while conservative hybrid funds with lower equity caps may miss out on maximizing upside potential. BAFs, on the other hand, have a dynamic and unconstrained approach, optimizing returns in all market environments.
When choosing a suitable BAF, it is important to track the fund manager's record in navigating different markets, evaluate the extent of allocation shifts between equity and debt over the past 5-10 years, consider the consistency and success of returns across bull and bear phases, and assess factors such as portfolio churn, expense ratios, and the experience of the fund management team.
BAFs provide flexibility and can serve as all-season funds across economic cycles. They are a robust long-term investment choice suitable for various financial needs. It is advisable to evaluate both quantitative and qualitative parameters before selecting a BAF as an investment vehicle.

item.title: ChainUp Earns Prestigious “Best Institutional Custody & Asset-Service” Recognition at the 2023 Regulation Asia Awards for Excellence
item.description: ChainUP, a global blockchain technology service provider, has been recognized at the 2023 Regulation Asia Awards for Excellence. The company was awarded "Best Institutional Custody & Asset-Service Solution" under the digital assets category. The award recognizes ChainUP's crypto custody and asset-servicing solutions that offer bank-grade security architecture, advanced legal and compliance controls, and flexibility for self-management of digital asset investments. The judging panel highlighted the robustness of ChainUP's solution, its regulatory risk minimization, and features such as configuration flexibility, private key recovery tool, and trading workflow integration capabilities. ChainUP's custody solution offers advanced security features to mitigate single-point-of-failure risk and enhance the security of self-managed assets. The company has also attained four internationally recognized security accreditations. The Chief Operating Officer of ChainUP expressed gratitude for the award and stated their commitment to empowering businesses and institutions globally to handle digital assets securely and in adherence to regulations. ChainUP offers end-to-end blockchain technology solutions and serves more than 1,000 clients in 30 countries.

Israel allowed 24,000 liters of diesel fuel to be delivered for UN aid distribution, but not for use at hospitals. The limited delivery of fuel is just 9% of what is needed daily to sustain life-saving activities in Gaza. The lack of fuel has caused the closure of hospitals, bakeries, and sewage pumping stations, as well as threatening to shut down telecoms data centers and connection points. The UN had warned that it may have to halt humanitarian operations if its fuel stocks became fully depleted. However, aid workers say the initial delivery of fuel is not enough to meet the needs of hospitals or aid deliveries. Despite the delivery of food and supplies, the aid distribution has been significantly affected due to the lack of fuel. Israel had previously refused to allow fuel in, fearing it would be used by Hamas. The Israeli military campaign against Hamas began in response to Hamas fighters crossing into southern Israel. The conflict has resulted in numerous casualties on both sides.

item.title: Rescuers search for survivors after lethal Russian missile strike in east Ukraine
item.description: A Russian missile struck an apartment block in the town of Selydove in eastern Ukraine, killing one person and injuring at least three others. The attack occurred shortly after midnight, with four S-300 missiles hitting the town and damaging multiple buildings. Local officials believe that four people may still be trapped under the rubble. The targeted area was comprised of civilians, not soldiers. Witnesses described the devastation caused by the missile, with one resident expressing fear for her own safety. Russia has been conducting regular missile and drone strikes on population centers in Ukraine, though Moscow denies intentionally targeting civilians. Ukraine has consistently reported civilian casualties and infrastructure damage resulting from Russia's invasion.

item.title: Sensex, Nifty rally more than 1 pc as investors cheer softer US inflation number
item.description: The benchmark equity indices in Mumbai, Sensex and Nifty, both increased by over 1% on Wednesday due to heavy buying in IT, banking, and oil & gas sectors. This was part of a global stocks rally following softer US inflation data, which raised hopes for an end to interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The Sensex rose 742.06 points or 1.14% to a four-week high of 65,675.93, while the Nifty50 climbed 231.90 points or 1.19% to 19,675.45. The market saw gains in various sectors including tech, automotive, and energy. Additionally, Asian and European markets were trading in the green, and the US markets ended with significant gains. Foreign institutional investors offloaded equities worth RS 1,244.44 crore on Tuesday. Retail inflation in India for October reached a four-month low of 4.87%, while wholesale price inflation remained negative for the seventh consecutive month. These economic changes have sparked optimism and are expected to draw foreign investment into emerging markets, benefiting the Indian economy.

item.title: Russian resources minister visits North Korea amid new missile development
item.description: A Russian delegation, led by natural resources minister Alexander Kozlov, visited Pyongyang, North Korea. The visit came as the politically isolated state announced progress in its banned ballistic missile program. The talks between Russia and North Korea focused on the economy, science, and technology. Kozlov emphasized Russia's desire for substantial cooperation with North Korea based on agreements made by Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Meanwhile, a cultural delegation from North Korea traveled to St. Petersburg for an event. South Korea's intelligence agency stated that North Korea is in the final stages of preparing for the launch of a spy satellite, potentially with technical assistance from Russia. North Korean state media reported successful static tests of new high-thrust solid-fuel engines for intermediate-range ballistic missiles (IRBMs). These tests are seen as essential for enhancing North Korea's military capabilities in a challenging security environment. Solid-fuel missiles are considered easier to operate and more survivable than liquid-fuel weapons. Both North Korea's missile program and its nuclear weapons are prohibited by UN Security Council resolutions, leading to imposed sanctions. The US has accused North Korea of supplying military equipment to Russia for use in the war with Ukraine, while Moscow is alleged to provide technical military support to North Korea. However, both countries deny these claims and pledge closer military cooperation.

item.title: Analysis-Advances give Sudanese paramilitary force momentum in seven-month war
item.description: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Sudan have made significant gains in their war with the army, breaking months of stalemate. These gains have strengthened the RSF's position and influence in talks in Jeddah. While there is speculation about the possibility of Sudan splitting, it remains unclear how the RSF could govern a breakaway territory. Instead, the RSF aims to increase its access to resources, such as gold, and secure its role in any political settlement. The RSF has been expanding its control in various regions, including Darfur and Khartoum, and has expressed its intention to reach Port Sudan. However, there is currently no immediate risk of Sudan splitting. The war between the RSF and the army began after a plan to integrate the two forces fell apart. The RSF has been gradually gaining territory and has recently used drones and longer-range artillery. The army has faced challenges with repairs to its warplanes and fatigue among soldiers. The RSF's advances have exacerbated the humanitarian crisis in Sudan, with thousands of casualties and millions displaced. Ceasefire talks in Jeddah have been adjourned without a resolution, with the RSF seeking checkpoints and outposts to formalize its role in Khartoum. The army is under pressure from Bashir loyalists and Islamist militias. The situation remains volatile, and ethnically targeted violence is likely to persist.

item.title: Biden, Xi meet as US-China military, economic tensions grind on
item.description: US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are meeting for the first time in a year to discuss military conflicts, drug-trafficking, and artificial intelligence. However, deep progress on economic issues may have to wait. The expectations for the meeting are low, as the leaders have been unable to resolve long-standing disagreements on various topics such as Taiwan, the South China Sea, the Israel-Hamas war, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, North Korea, and human rights. The meeting is taking place on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in San Francisco. Demonstrations for and against China's ruling communist party have taken place in the city. Biden has been cultivating a personal relationship with Xi in hopes of salvaging bilateral ties. The meeting is expected to address issues such as Iran's actions, Chinese influence operations in foreign elections, and the status of US citizens detained in China. Concrete steps are expected to be taken on issues ranging from military communications to managing the flow of fentanyl and artificial intelligence technologies. Biden is expected to assure Xi that US commitments in the Indo-Pacific region remain unchanged, particularly regarding the security of the Philippines.

item.title: Central Europe’s defence companies spy African opportunity
item.description: Central European defense companies are aiming to expand their sales of weapons, military equipment, and related services in Africa. Former Warsaw Pact countries, such as the Czech Republic, have a history of supplying weapons to African nations during the Communist era and are now well-positioned to upgrade these systems. The shift towards Western technology by African countries still using Soviet-era equipment provides new opportunities for Central European defense companies. These companies are negotiating deals for guns, ammunition, military equipment, and services with various African nations. Their expertise in maintaining and modernizing Eastern-origin military land systems appeals to African customers who want to reduce reliance on Russian suppliers. With concerns over the reliability of Russian arms, there is potential for Central European defense companies to fill the gap. Russia has become the leading arms seller in sub-Saharan Africa, but the expertise of Czech industry in former Soviet weapons presents a valuable advantage. Polish defense companies have also intensified their talks with African markets, and interest has increased from potential African customers in Poland. The Czech Republic recently sent a trade mission to several African countries, focusing on boosting opportunities for the defense industry. Reopening and strengthening relationships with traditional partners in Africa is a key goal. Defense industry cooperation is seen as an integral part of these efforts. The Czech arms industry's reputation has been enhanced through its efforts to supply Ukraine in response to Russia's invasion in 2022. As African countries using Soviet-style equipment start to view Russia as a problematic supplier, they are turning to Central European alternatives.

He pointed out that elections are also scheduled in Rajasthan and Telangana in the coming days. The counting of votes for these states, along with Mizoram, will be held on December 3.
